review_title: Cal Poly, SLO doesn't value or reward IT professionals
job_title: Operating Systems Analyst in San Luis Obispo, CA
pros: Nice place to live (but expensive!)
cons:
Salaries are low, something like 60% of going rate for IT professionals.  Our union gave up any notion of raises about 10 years ago, so people from before that are much better paid.  People that were hired more recently are hired at low pay and never get a raise.  Morale is low.  The typical way people get more money is to move from position to position.

Many IT managers are from the "good old days" and take care of their jobs and their buddies, but don't take care of business.  Many IT managers are completely stale technically, and have little relevant knowledge or skills in current IT practices, and poor management skills.

The review system is fundamentally broken, good people are not rewarded and under performers are not dealt with, so they good people give up and leave, and the under performers get more and more entrenched.  Many  IT staff have been here far too long, are basically "retired in place" and get in the way of doing the right thing to protect their positions.

Old managers and old staff like the "good old ways" of doing things.  Don't come here to do anything cutting edge.

review_title: Good for a small job, bad for big expectations
job_title: Web Programmer in San Luis Obispo, CA
pros: Flexible hours, friendly staff, good onsite software access (full adobe suite and more). You need a small job to fill in the gaps while on campus, this may be it.
cons:
You do all your work through Druple and it can easily double the time it takes to do otherwise simple html formatting. On the plus side, that means you get paid more for the same result. But that leads to the main issue, which is the absolute content drought. My employer did not understand the simplicity of much of the work he gave me. I was explicitly led to believe that I could work nearly full time during the summer, but just two weeks into the summer I discovered that I would be scrambling to meet even half that time. I ended up having to dramatically rework my finances (I was planning a move and to buy a vehicle) and get a new job.

Do not assume you will have a lot of work unless you see the amount of work for yourself. Make sure your manager's expectation are crystal clear, leave no room for ambiguity.

review_title: Cal Poly Corp doesn't care about Cal Poly's values, only turning a profit
job_title: Cook in San Luis Obispo, CA
pros: Constant availability means its fairly easy to get a job here, and easy to get enough hours if you need money. A set quarterly schedule for workers means you don't have a constantly changing schedule like other employers at Cal Poly. "Free-meal passes" are a little bonus each time you work at least four hours.
cons: No benefits, great reluctance to offer "full-time" positions. Instead they rely on a constant stream of "interim" employees which basically means they'll work you full-time then replace you with someone else after a few months. Students are treated as disposable, and management will simply take them off the schedule to cut back on paid hours without even notifying them. Instead of offering quality food their dining division offers extremely cheap, overpriced food at the expense of its students.

job_title: Student Assistant in San Luis Obispo, CA

review_title: Hard working, motivated, loyal and determined.
job_title: Custodian in Pomona, CA

cons: There is not much room for advancement without a masters or doctoral degree.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Luis Obispo, CA
pros: The salary is fine, the benefits are great, and the environment is generally friendly. A positive side effect of the dismal state budgets is that you usually work in small, tight-knit teams and feel like you're "making a difference."
cons: Top-heavy management structure, limited room for growth. I acquired all of my departed supervisor's duties for five months and was never compensated accordingly. Helplessly self-aware of its own bureaucracy, nothing happens as smoothly as it could.

review_title: Great Environment to Work in As A Student
job_title: Student Assistant in San Luis Obispo, CA

job_title: in Cal Poly SLO, CA

review_title: Beautiful location, nice people, but overworked and underpaid
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Luis Obispo, CA

Staff hired are best of the best (despite being paid little). Nestled between San Francisco and L.A. in a very temperate climate.
cons: Staff across campus is overworked and underpaid, very few perks ($40 per month for gym membership). Frequent turnover. Very little financial support for personal professional development.

review_title: Great place to wok.  Hard to get in, though.

review_title: Amazing boss and work environment for an assistant job, but the department heads had ulterior motives .

review_title: It was a second home to me and made college a more fulfilling experience.
